https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80060,2018,International Law and Regulation,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['mr.dr. JA van Ast', 'prof.dr. P Mascini']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>By means of formulating and interpreting norms, law plays an important role in creating and upholding social order. The nation state is of great significance for law. However, nation states are embedded in larger political, legal, and economic institutions such as the EU, NATO, WTO, and the UN. The treaties and laws which are formulated at the supranational level, pertain to the domestic level as well. One of the aims of supranational legislation is to address cross border societal problems in a unifying and harmonizing way. One can think of environmental problems such as climate change, deforestation, and pollution and work related problems emanating from global production chains such as exploitation and unhealthy and unsafe working conditions. Such border crossing problem cases accrue in prevalence and magnitude as a result of a globalizing economy. So far, domestic and international legislation have had limited success in handling these societal problems. This is one of the reasons why business and civil society have recently become increasingly involved in the formulation, monitoring, and enforcement of standards for products and services. Moreover, the private regulation of markets interacts with law at different levels and in different ways. This course first deals with the fundamentals of law and the manner in which supranational law is incorporated in domestic law. What is law? What public law, civil law, administrative law, criminal law? What do important legal concepts mean, like constitution, legality, rule of law, separation of powers, attribution, delegation, mandate, authority, act, regulation etc. And international law, with its many regulations and institutions, what is it actually about? Subsequently, the course deals with private regulation and the mutual interaction between (international) law and private regulation. Which private parties are involved in private regulation, and how? Under what conditions are these private forms of regulation more or less likely to succeed? When do law and private regulation act as substitutes? When are they complementary or conflicting? The focus is on the handling of cross national social problem cases spurred on by a globalizing economy. The first half of the course aims at answering these questions with a comprehensive introduction in the study of law. The second half of the course reflects on the changing role of law and regulation in contemporary society.  </body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>After following this course, the student is able:

column2: • to place conflicts, questions and issues in the different fields of law;
• to present the most important changes in terms of law during recent history;
• to reproduce the main elements of the legal organization of a Western democratic unitarian state and administration;
• to reproduce the role of law and of the state in modern society;
• to reproduce the legal background of the most important institutions in international law (EU, UN, CoE);
• to point out how international public law influences national law;
• to define some of the basic legal concepts and position these concepts in modern governance, the state, international institutional relations and in international environmental law;
• to define regulation;
• to reproduce the dominant view on recent trends in regulation in terms of actors, instruments and goals as well as the limitations of this dominant view;
• to assess the tenability of the assumption that private international regulation can close the gap that is left by public international regulation;
• to understand the relationship between public and private regulation.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Organizations base their strategies on information about consumers, industrial buyers, distributors, employees, competitors, and suppliers. The International Marketing Research course deals with how to collect and analyze this information. The course builds on the knowledge acquired during previous methodology courses and combines it to address managerial problems such as demand forecasting, market segmentation, and new product design.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: This course aims at enabling you to approach managerial problems scientifically: understand the kind of research that problems require, conduct such research, and use research findings to make informed decisions. Although the course deals with problems that are usually faced by marketing practitioners, you will develop skills that are readily applicable to other disciplines, such as Business and Society Management, Corporate Finance, and organizational research.
The abilities that you will be expected to learn include:

column5: Mastering the main sources of marketing data and methods of market research;
Choosing the best method to approach a certain problem;
Collecting qualitative and quantitative data;
Analyzing these data and evaluate existing analyses;
Drawing conclusions for your marketing problem;
Translating your conclusions into concrete managerial actions.

column3: At the end of this course you should have acquired or improved your skills in:

column5: Analytical thinking;
Problem identification/solving;
Statistical analysis.

column3: Moreover, because of the structure of the course, you will develop skills in group work and academic writing.</mystyle></body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80255,2018,International Migration,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. FG Snel'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course gives a basic introduction in international migration and various related phenomena. The course focuses on the causes of international migration and the consequences of international migration in both sending and receiving countries. We will discuss extensively economic and sociological theories that try to explain why people migrate from one country to another, and often from one part of the world to the other. A second major issue in the course are the consequences of migration for sending countries and communities, Does migration contribute to economic and social development in sensing communities? And what are the consequences for receiving countries, in terms of both the socio-economic (or ‘structural’) integration of migrants and the socio-cultural integration (or ‘assimilation) of migrants or lack of assimilation and resulting cultural diversity in receiving countries and communities where many migrants settle?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have insight in the size and character of international migration processes in various parts of the world, both in the presence and in the past
• Have solid understanding of economic and sociological theories about factors that contribute to the rise and continuation of processes of international migration
• Understand to what extent and how migration policies and migration control of receiving countries are able to steer international migration flows

• Understand and are able to take a substantiated position about whether or not, or under what conditions, international migration contributes to the economic development of and social relations in sending communities

• Understand and are able to take a substantiated position about whether or not, or under what conditions, international migration results in growing socio-economic inequality and socio-cultural diversity in receiving countries

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80430,2018,International Organisations & the EU as an International Actor,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. T Ertuna Lagrand, LL.M']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Public International Organizations form the structural web of co-operative relationships between states. They have also become elements of the modern state’s institutional system and of its public administration. Within this global system, the European Union embodies the most far-reaching expression of international cooperation, in terms of its system of governance, level of integration as well as the extent of its competences. Accordingly, the EU has a range of competences in external relations at varying levels depending on the field of the particular external action.

This course is designed for students with limited or no prior knowledge into the study of international organizations or the European Union and (the legal basis of) its foreign policy. The course will first of all familiarize the students with the law of international organizations, the body of rules, principles and concepts governing the functioning of international organizations. This will be followed by an introduction to the EU, in particular its history, institutions and competence. The course will then focus on different fields of EU external action, and analyse EU’s level of competence, the legal instruments at its disposal and current developments in each of these fields.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand the basic legal and institutional structures governing the functioning of international organizations, and thereby grasp in structural terms, the international system of which modern states operate in;
• Understand the steps of European integration, as well as the constitutional and institutional foundations of European external relations;

• Develop a proficiency in recognizing EU’s competence, tools, policy choices and role in different strands of EU external action such as enlargement, association, neighbourhood, development, humanitarian aid, trade, common foreign and security policy; and the coordination thereof;
• Analyze EU relations with other international actors from a structural and legal framework.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will be significantly different than any other course you have ever taken. Its design is such that it has features of both a course and a competitive consulting assignment. The elective covers many aspects of branding, marketing and communications in a challenging way. We focus on digital & data, corporate social responsibility & purpose and neuromarketing.
L’Oréal is offering the marketing students of Erasmus University a unique opportunity to play the role of consultant, and dive into a very dynamic, real-life, practical assignment.
At the same time, the selective is designed such that teams will be able to build inspiring and well-underpinned brand experiences by applying the right concepts, methods and techniques.

It provides the opportunity to develop marketing and consulting skills through a practical, real-life experience, the chance to work closely with professionals in their field, and the possibility of winning a contest at one of several levels. All of these can contribute to one’s clarification of what kind of professional career could be interesting to pursue (or not) in the future. Being able to discuss the experience and what was learned with future employers. The course as it is designed, is a lot of work, and a lot of fun to apply marketing and strategy models and techniques learned during their study in a real-life business situation.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Learn about the current challenges in the practice of marketing, branding and advertising
• Digital marketing and use of data
• Corporate social responsibility and brand purpose
• Latest insights in neuroscience and implications for marketing
• Learn the newest insights from various practitioners
• Apply marketing and strategy models and techniques learned during your study in a real-life business situation;
• Build a persuasive, idea selling presentation with irresistible logic;
• Design and conduct quantitative and qualitative research to underpin your idea;
• Present your ideas with strongly improved presentation skills;
• Develop a brand experience and an integrated marketing communications campaign;
• Work effectively in teams

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80100,2018,International Relations & Human Rights Law,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['MM van der Gaag, MSc', 'N Tilahun', 'PK Livaha, LLM', 'prof.dr. M Onderco']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The minor will explore how governments, non-governmental organisations and international institutions interact in their efforts to protect human rights.

State sovereignty and international relations have a profound impact on the ability of the international community to respond to gross human rights violations. Thus, in this course, the positive and negative impacts of domestic politics and transnational actors and the collision of human rights ideals with the doctrine of state sovereignty will be recurring themes. Instruments of statecraft ranging from diplomacy, monitoring and mediation to peacekeeping and humanitarian military intervention are depicted and analyzed in the light of case studies.

The course will examine unresolved practical, theoretical (and maybe philosophical) issues and questions concerning the universality of human rights; whose responsibility it is to protect human rights; and whether human rights conventions, laws, and regimes are effective. Thus, the course looks at the juxtaposition of the traditional claims of states to guard sovereignty and impose order against more recent claims by individuals to freedom, rights, justice, universal moral order and humane treatment.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: 1)      Understanding the theories and issues of International Relations
2)      Understanding foundational values and basic doctrines of fundamental rights, being able to apply the latter in concrete cases

3)      Understanding the interaction between sovereignty concerns for states with ‘legitimacy concerns’ of international courts, and being able to identify the tension with the effective protection of fundamental rights.
4)      Understanding the role of interpretation principles characteristic of human rights in this regard.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81183,2018,International Relations Theory,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. D Fazzi', 'dr. RJ Adriaansen', 'drs. TW Bottelier']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Master Global History and International Relations attempts to combine history and theory. In this course the focus is on theory: International Relations Theory (IRT). We  will, however, try  to  connect theory and history, more particularly the problem of using theory in historical research. We hope that this may help you to write your MA thesis research proposal in the Research Workshop.The Oxford Handbook of International Relations (2008) offers  a  comprehensive  overview of the  field of international relations. It  debates  the  nature  of the  field,  critically  engages  with  the  major  theories, and examines the field's relation with other disciplines. This course  studies  and discusses  selected articles of the  Oxford Handbook to  introduce  the  subject of international relations  studies. The selection  of chapters  is  complemented  by  a  series  of articles  on  Non-Western  International Relations, focusing on East-Asia. During class we will apply theories of international relations to historical and contemporary issues, like the ‘The  Opium Wars  in China  in the  19th century’,  ‘Humanitarian crises in Ethiopia and Somalia’, ‘The Iraq War’ and ‘The European Union’.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can present and discuss major theories of western and non-western international relations
• Students can compare major theories of international relations
• Students can elaborate on the possibilities and difficulties of using IR theories for historical research
• Students can apply IR theories to historical cases

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80429,2018,International Relations: Theories, Approaches & Themes",Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['B Hesseling, MA', 'PK Livaha, LLM']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: This course will address several important issues that we all discuss in our daily lives like the US intervention in Iraq, power politics and the efficiency of international organisations. The course aims to introduce students to the main themes of International Relations, such as world system, wars, nuclear weapons, interstate relations, international organizations and the role of international institutions. The second part of the course covers neglected issues about the ‘other’ side of world politics, for instance environmental issues, the problems of the developing world, gendered-biases, the construction of partial knowledge, the legitimization of power politics, the representation of images, establishment of stereotypes and the reproduction of hegemony. Rather than discussing each issue or only practical cases, the course attempts to explain theories in order to help students formulate their world view. Since theories are essential for understanding and explaining the world, students will learn about the different theories and approaches developed within the discipline of International Relations (IR). It is important in this course that students become aware of the theoretical richness of the discipline, and that there is not a single ‘right’ way to answer questions about what is happening around us in the world. Students will learn about each IR theory in tutorial meetings. They are also given a chance to apply those theories to different and more specific cases and issues. For this reason, this course is not only aiming at giving theoretical insights to the students but also an opportunity to apply and use them. Case studies or specific issues are provided by the course literature. In addition to this, in some tutorial meetings, students will be asked to bring news items of their own choice from newspapers and news agencies. Thus, the course is based on active student participation.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Students will understand how major scholars have theorized international relations; assess contributions and short-comings of both mainstream and alternative theories; enhance their analytical skills and develop capacity to engage in complex political issues; demonstrate how theory provides a road map by which to examine international events and processes.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79199,2018,International Trade Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. A Erbahar', 'M Haasbroek']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Why do countries trade? Is everyone better off from trade? Why and how do governments use trade policy instruments and how do they affect the economy? What is the role of the WTO and what can explain the proliferation of trade agreements? These are some of the questions we will explore in this course. We will begin by reviewing the traditional trade models of Ricardo and Hecksher-Ohlin, and identify the winners and losers from trade. Then we will study the instruments of trade policy and their effects. The course will then move to the political economy of trade policy to understand what determines trade policy, and we will conclude by studying the world trading system, paying special attention to the role of the WTO and regional trade agreements.
The following topics will be covered during this course:

column2: • Introduction to Trade and Trade Policy
• Comparative Advantage
• Trade and Resources
• Trade Policy Instruments and their effects
• Political Economy of Trade Policy
• Multilateral Trade Negotiations and the Rise of FTA's

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/84271,2018,International Trade and Transport Regulation,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['ir. K Wassens', 'J Thoms - van der Heul']",,"Inhoud

<body>This module fosters insight in the commercial transaction. Focus will lay on the law of Agency, Sale of Goods, Documents, Financing and Transportation. Many people can be involved in an international trade transaction.  Through the concept of Agency, a person can benefit from, or be liable for, the actions of another person.  The transaction creates duties and liabilities for the parties to the contract of sale, which need to be understood.  Then, the sales price has to be paid and the goods have to be carried to the buyer.  In an international context, with parties that don't necessarily trust each other, these operations create legal challenges. Throughout these subjects the Bill of Lading  plays a central role. This document entitles its holder to claim the goods from the carrier, it serves as a title to the goods, and it will be used as security in the financing operations.  The Bill of Lading is also very important to the Customs; it is, for instance, a crucial document in the customs risk assessment of the customs declaration.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1.       Understand the concepts of agency, sale of goods, carriage of goods, commercial documents, documentary payment, letters of credit and transportation;
2.       Understand the network of contracts, the interplay and the possibilities to break through the network of contracts;
3.       Understand the basic principles of contract, property law and tort;
4.       Apply the various concepts in analysing a complex case.

<body>This course introduces students to the core themes in international communication studies. The course pays special attention to the historical, politico-economic, social, cultural, and technological factors that have shaped both (1) communication relations across the globe and (2) the way in which we think about these relations.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The key developments in international communication and international communication research since the mid-20th century;
• The different factors that affect communication flows across the globe;
• The relevance of paying attention to local contexts of production and consumption in order to study global media processes;
• New technologies' challenges and opportunities for international communication.
• Analyze and critically reflect upon existing international communication research;
• Apply key concepts from the course to the study and assessment of local, national, transnational, and supranational communication processes;
• Engage in an informed and critical way in pressing contemporary debates, such as those related to the world information society and to communication rights;
• Work in international and intercultural groups to assess issues related to international communication.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The International Business Project is a consultancy-like project. International teams of 3-5 CEMS students solve a real business problem as a one-semester part-time activity tutored by both the company and a professor in parallel.
Each CEMS student must carry out a Business Project during Term 2. It amounts to 15 ECTS, which is about 50% of Term 2's workload.
International business projects reinforce the CEMS partnership between universities and companies in jointly shaping the student learning process in international management.

column2: <tbody>

column4: The Challenge of Intercultural and Inter-organisational Learning

column1: Project results are evaluated by the academic and corporate supervisors. Students write a report and give an oral presentation, both as a group.
Students are thus offered the opportunity to:

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80808,2018,International business strategy,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. BC Pinkham'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Over the last few decades the international competitive environment in which firms operate has changed. Shortening of product life cycles due to rapid technological change and globalization of markets have intensified competition for the multinational enterprise (MNE). The intensification of external pressures requires (future) managers to be able to understand and swiftly reply to such market changes. This international strategy course is primarily designed to provide (future) managers with the knowledge how to create and sustain competitive advantage in an international market place in the form of firm internationalization.

From an integrative managerial perspective we will explore multiple global and local forces that MNCs face in their international environments. Developing and implementing strategic choices is the mainstay of successful decision-making in an international environment. This course will help the student to develop the essential skills needed to formulate and implement these strategic moves. In doing so, we will consider many of the paradoxes and trade-offs that confront the international business strategist and managers in global value chains.

The course is designed to take a deeper dive into key concepts from Strategy Management encapsulated by three general topics of international business and strategy: 1) internationalization motives and entry modes; 2) cultural implications of operating in a global environment; 3) international operations and strategy (strategic implementation).

The main teaching methods in this course are lectures, discussion, and team assignments. Since a typical class day will be based on discussion of practical examples, the course is highly interactive in nature and requires students’ committed participation. This will provide an opportunity for divergent perspectives to be aired, which is important in courses of this nature, where there are seldom “right” or “wrong” answers. To be able to properly utilize the learning opportunity of this course, students should adequately prepare the material in advance of each class day as it facilitates the process of teamwork and class discussion.
This course is worth 3 ECTS (1 foundation ECT and 2 master ECTS).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Extend core concepts from Strategic Management (e.g., domestic setting) to an international setting,
<li>
Analyze the challenges of doing business abroad through applied examples,
<li>
Develop an understanding of why firms internationalize, and
<li>
Learn how firms may choose to enter foreign markets.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80903,2018,International entrepreneurship: From start-up to scale-up,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. W Hulsink'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

One manifestation of our globalizing world is the emergence of innovative start-ups that have a worldwide focus and sometimes resource base from inception. The international activities of these firms that have decided to go abroad almost directly after their creation, have received an increasing amount of attention over the past years; they are called born globals or international new ventures. In addition to small and medium-sized firms with incremental growth strategies, the focus in this course is on these dynamic start-up firms that make products and sell services that are ‘new to the world’, strive for scaling up their activities and seek international presence. These growth-oriented start-ups with global expansion strategies face a lot of uncertainty compared to established multinational companies with more traditional products and services: their novel products or services are unknown to the market, so is the effect of the product for the customer. Also, in bringing these niche products and services to the international market, young firms have limited resources and few complementary assets (they do not have deep pockets and needed additional start-up and growth financing). In this course we will look how innovative start-ups and ambitious small firms mitigate the risks starting-up, early growth and internationalization, and more specifically how they address and manage their country selection and market investigation, their entry mode choice(s) and international operations and capabilities. Other interesting characteristics of these international new ventures are the importance of the founders and the entrepreneurial team, their particular motives for international expansion, and the relevance of strategic partners and investors.

The course will be composed of (guest) lectures, a case assignment, and a field project. Lectures will introduce the students to the (international) entrepreneurship literature and apply it through discussing cases on growing/internationalizing entrepreneurs and their firms in class. Guest speakers, e.g. entrepreneurs, investors, and business facilitators, will cover the more practical aspects and hands-on tactics and tricks in the domain of international entrepreneurship. Blending theory and practice will be created through doing a case assignment. In this assignment, teams of students will produce a teaching case and a teaching note on an internationalizing new venture/young firm. Students will pick and study an entrepreneurial firm in its growth and internationalization efforts, and more specifically focus on a strategic choice the entrepreneur and his/her firm has made, and prepare a teaching case and an instructor’s note for class discussion. Blending of theory and practice will also be created through the development of a field project. This includes applying the literature, collecting external data and/or contacting people for outside help, writing a report and/or running an entrepreneurial project, and presenting your work. The purpose is to work with the entrepreneurship theory in real-life situations, for example, by developing a specific checklist / roadmap for entrepreneurs or investors, producing a generic advisory report or doing a business consultancy project.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course, students should be able to:

column2: • identify key entrepreneurial processes (start-up and growth, opportunity identification, new venture planning, bootstrapping, etc.) and explain the key role of entrepreneurial initiative in creating new organizations and building economic activity;
• describe the leading concepts, models and tools in the field of (international) entrepreneurship, and how to transfer them to practice and apply them;
• identify distinctive characteristics of the start-up, growth, and internationalization process of young/small firms;

• recognize the opportunities and risks offered by different institutional settings of nations or regions and to understand their relevance for and influence on starting and growing of young/small firms;
• compare and evaluate (dis)advantages of different internationalization strategies (country/market selection, models of entry: exporting, partnering, joint venturing, investing, and acquiring);

• to discuss and assess the contribution of International New Ventures / Born Global Firms (start-ups/young firms searching for global niche markets) to the International Management literature and practice.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80899,2018,International strategy,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. BC Pinkham'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will leverage academic articles, practical applications of theory, and cases to develop the students’ ability to analyze international strategy issues. Students will have the opportunity to demonstrate their understanding of core concepts through weekly quizzes and class discussion. They will end the course with a group project.

We will focus on three core theories of international strategy: Industry-, Resource-, and Institution-based views. Individually, these theories provided the building blocks for international strategy. Porter (1980) introduced what we now call the industry-based view to help managers better understand competitive dynamics in industries. In the mid 80’s and early 90’s, the revival of resource-based approaches elaborating Penrose (1952) helped to explain how firms may develop capabilities and combine and leverage resources to gain sustained competitive advantages (Barney, 1991; Dierickx & Cool, 1989). And more recently, a group of scholars has been promoting the inclusion of an institution-based view to help explain the rules of game that may shape business and firm outcomes. Together, these theories create the basis for a strategy tripod.

The strategy tripod helps managers to better understand four key questions (Peng et al., 2009): Why do firms differ? How do firms behave? What determines the scope of the firm? What determines the success and failure of firms around the globe? Each of these questions relates to firm performance, the fundamental focus of strategy practitioners and researchers and the core of our course.

I strive to evaluate all available information to arrive at a final grade that fairly reflects the student’s demonstrated capability in dealing with and understanding the international strategy course content. Evidence of this capability is recorded in this course through classroom contribution, quizzes, and a final, group report. I have attempted to strike a balance between individual and group assignments. The grade in this course is a composite of class contribution, quizzes based on case preparation and assigned readings, and a group project. I will use the following to evaluate your written and non-written work:

column2: <tbody>
</tbody>

column1: Class contribution (10%)  I will keep a record of class participation for all students and assess your contributions based on the quality of in-class comments. There will be no quantity component, and to encourage articulate and thoughtful comments I will take the highest score from the following scale to give session grades:
Marginal Quality: 1 (Overly long, confusing, or distracting comments)
Good Quality: 3 (Moves discussion along, shows basic understanding)
High Quality: 6 (Analyzes and adds to discussion)
Exceptional: 12 (Exceptional, integrates multiple sources from course materials)
In a class with our size, most comments should be Good (3) and High Quality (6). Exceptional (12) comments occur only two or three times a term.

Quizzes (50%) Students will respond to a series of True/False and multiple-choice questions each class session. The questions will be drawn from assigned readings, cases, and lectures. Some questions may extend concepts from prior sessions to emphasize differences or counter-intuitive outcomes, and may also be used to reinforce key concepts and ideas. We will leverage the quizzes in class to start discussion.

Theory and Practice (40%) Students will work in groups to deliver a presentation and written evaluation on a firm of their choice. The project presentation should include three major sections: identification of case issues(s), analysis of the issue(s), and recommendations. Your analysis should be based on the information you find through research, media articles, and field interviews. I will evaluate your presentation based on its quality and reasonableness relating to MNE strategies. I expect to see good “business presenting.” Everyone must participate in the final presentation.
(Week 41) – Bring questions to class about presentations and case write-ups
(Week 42) – Case presentations in class, final write-ups due at 5pm!
1. International strategy issue (needs to have some international or cross-border tie);
2. Follow the Case Plan Example (end of syllabus), you must write both a case and teaching note;
3. Shorter cases (5-7 pages) are always in high demand. Your goal should be close to this!
4. Delivered digitally (pinkham@rsm.nl), by 5pm on the last day of class.
Successful cases may be further developed for submission to Ivey or HBS.

Students are expected to contribute substantially to group work. Every student understands that all group members are equally responsible for the entire project unless otherwise indicated by the professor. Students completing team assignments will receive the same grade as their team members for the group report, with one exception. The professor may request each student to independently evaluate the contribution of other group members. If substantial concerns arise from these evaluations the professor reserves the right to individually assign outcomes.

Attendance of all university sessions is compulsory. If you miss a session, you must inform me (pinkham@rsm.nl) prior to the session. Students who miss 2 or more session will have their final grades reduced by 0.3 points.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The objective of this course is to develop students’ understanding of how international operations differ from domestics ones. It provides students with the necessary knowledge for a career or further study in international business.
We will focus on four outcomes. By the end of the term:
1. The student will be able to integrate both theory and practice to address international strategy cases;
2. The student will defend a choice relevant to international strategy of MNEs (e.g., location choice or entry mode) using a theory (or framework);
3. The student will distinguish between the three, leading international strategy perspectives and be able to identify the strengths and weakness of each;
4. Students (in groups) will analyze and develop/create an international strategy case to show their understanding of core international strategy concepts.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79137,2018,Internationale economie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. J Emami Namini', 'prof.dr. EM Bosker']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Het vak Internationale economie houdt zich vooral bezig met de wereldeconomie als zodanig en de betrekkingen tussen landen en handelsblokken, op het gebied van internationale handel, kapitaalstromen, economische groei, wisselkoersen, financiële verstoringen, enzovoort. Hoewel uiteindelijk macro-economische grootheden centraal staan zullen deze meestal vanuit een micro-economische fundering worden opgebouwd. Daarnaast gebruiken internationaal economen regelmatig ideeen/concepten die ook hun oorsprong hebben in andere subdisciplines van de economie (bijv. micro-/macro-economie, economische geografie, monetaire economie of ontwikkelingseconomie) Het resultaat is een rijk geschakeerd geheel aan inzichten dat helpt om de oorzaken en gevolgen van de internationale economische betrekkingen tussen landen beter te begrijpen.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Het begrijpen van de fundamentele theorieën en concepten in de theorie van de internationale handel, maar ook in de internationale financiële wereld.

• Het verkrijgen van kennis over de wereld economie als zodanig en de relaties tussen landen en handelsblokken betreffende de internationale handel, kapitaalstromen, de economische groei, wisselkoersen en financiële crises.

• Verkrijgen van kennis van de macro-economische verhoudingen die de kern vormen van de analyse van de wereldeconomie, en tegelijkertijd te begrijpen dat deze relaties meestal zijn opgebouwd vanuit een micro-economisch perspectief.

• Verkrijgen van kennis over hoe de internationale economie vaak wordt geïnspireerd door thema's uit, bijvoorbeeld, aardrijkskunde, monetaire economie, econometrie, ontwikkeling of industriële organisatie.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81886,2018,Internationale grondslagen van de indirecte belastingen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. ML Schippers, LL.M', 'drs. T Braakman', 'EG Bakker, LL.M', 'J Gruson', 'MDC Gomes Vale Viga', 'mr. I van den Eijnde, LLM', 'prof.mr.dr. MMWD Merkx', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het mastervak Internationale grondslagen van de indirecte belastingen begint met de behandeling van de internationaalrechtelijke context van het WTO-recht en de invloed daarvan op de heffing van indirecte belastingen en douanerechten in EU-verband. Vervolgens komt de werking van het EU-recht aan de orde (waaronder de verhouding primair en secundair recht) alsmede de doorwerking van het EU-recht in de nationale rechtsorde. Ten slotte wordt de plaats van de BTW binnen de interne markt van de EU behandeld, waarbij aandacht wordt besteed aan het ‘EC-Action Plan on VAT: towards a single EU VAT Area’.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:

column2: • zelfstandig vraagstukken op het gebied van het internationale recht (WTO en WCO) en de invloed daarvan op indirecte belastingen en douane binnen het EU-recht te analyseren en op te lossen.
• de plaats van de indirecte belastingen en douanerechten binnen de EU interne markt te analyseren en te evalueren.
• complexe vraagstukken op het gebied van doorwerking van het EU-recht op de heffing van indirecte belastingen en het douanerecht te analyseren en op te lossen.

• de leerstukken van rechtstreekse werking van richtlijnen en rechtstreekse toepasselijkheid van verordeningen te onderscheiden, analyseren en evalueren en de rol van het HvJ EU bij de volle werking van het EU-recht te duiden.
• EU rechtsbeginselen toe te passen en te analyseren bij vraagstukken inzake indirecte belastingen en douanerecht.
• de structuur van de BTW-richtlijn en de wijze waarop deze bijdraagt aan de opheffing van de fiscale grenzen en het functioneren van de interne markt in de EU te onderkennen en te beschrijven.
• het ‘Action Plan on VAT: Towards a single EU VAT Area’ toe te passen en te analyseren in verhouding tot het huidige BTW-stelsel.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80471,2018,Internationale grondslagen van indirecte belastingen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['drs. T Braakman', 'MDC Gomes Vale Viga', 'mr. I van den Eijnde, LLM', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het mastervak Internationale grondslagen van de indirecte belastingen begint met de behandeling van de internationaalrechtelijke context van het WTO-recht en de invloed daarvan op de heffing van indirecte belastingen en douanerechten in EU-verband. Vervolgens komt de werking van het EU-recht aan de orde (waaronder de verhouding primair en secundair recht) alsmede de doorwerking van het EU-recht in de nationale rechtsorde. Ten slotte wordt de plaats van de BTW binnen de interne markt van de EU behandeld, waarbij aandacht wordt besteed aan het ‘EC-Action Plan on VAT: towards a single EU VAT Area’.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:

column2: • zelfstandig vraagstukken op het gebied van het internationale recht (WTO en WCO) en de invloed daarvan op indirecte belastingen en douane binnen het EU-recht te analyseren en op te lossen.
• de plaats van de indirecte belastingen en douanerechten binnen de EU interne markt te analyseren en te evalueren.
• complexe vraagstukken op het gebied van doorwerking van het EU-recht op de heffing van indirecte belastingen en het douanerecht te analyseren en op te lossen.

• de leerstukken van rechtstreekse werking van richtlijnen en rechtstreekse toepasselijkheid van verordeningen te onderscheiden, analyseren en evalueren en de rol van het HvJ EU bij de volle werking van het EU-recht te duiden.
• EU rechtsbeginselen toe te passen en te analyseren bij vraagstukken inzake indirecte belastingen en douanerecht.
• de structuur van de BTW-richtlijn en de wijze waarop deze bijdraagt aan de opheffing van de fiscale grenzen en het functioneren van de interne markt in de EU te onderkennen en te beschrijven.
• het ‘Action Plan on VAT: Towards a single EU VAT Area’ toe te passen en te analyseren in verhouding tot het huidige BTW-stelsel.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80469,2018,Internationale handel,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. ML Schippers, LL.M', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In het mastervak Internationale handel komen op geïntegreerde wijze de douanerechtelijke, btw- en civielrechtelijke aspecten ten aanzien van deze aan globalisering onderhevige goederenstromen aan bod. Het vak bouwt daarmee voort op de vakken Internationale grondslagen van de indirecte belastingen en EU-douanerecht en accijnzen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:

column2: • zelfstandig complexe vraagstukken vanuit btw- en douaneperspectief analyseren en oplossen op gebied van in- en uitvoer, intracommunautaire leveringen en de(her)structurering van complexe goederenstromen;
• de civielrechtelijke regelgeving met betrekking tot complexe internationale goederenstromen toe te passen op basis van de binnen dit vak verworven kennis en inzicht;
• de samenhang en de verschillen tussen de vaststelling van de douanewaarde enerzijds en verrekenprijzen anderzijds te analyseren;
• de samenloop tussen civielrechtelijke, btw- en douaneaspecten bij complexe internationale goederenstromen te onderkennen en te begrijpen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The internship comprises +- 10 weeks abroad. During the internship the students will work on an assignment, which can be more academically or more practically oriented. Students are divided into groups of three, ideally with one student from each university. In this way, they bring together their knowledge base and integrate it with that of the others.

Internship vacancies will be arranged and guaranteed before students start with the minor. Students who already know they will follow part B of the Minor will choose their internship in an early stage (during Part A of the Minor) in order to allow for proper preparation and arrangements. The students have to finance the internship (travel, accommodation and living costs) themselves, unless part of the costs is covered by the host organization. The latter only applies to board and lodging costs. The costs involved for an internship are to a large extent country and context specific but between 2,500 and 3,000 Euros is a realistic estimate of the costs involved.  Students will be provided with suggestions on where to find opportunities to apply for subsidies. In case extra help is necessary, student should contact the minor coordinators who will provide individual support.

The internship takes place from week 47 (starting 19 November 2018) until week 3-4 (14/21 January 2019). Students are guided by three supervisors. Firstly, every group of students receive supervision from their internship supervisor, who is one of the lecturers in Part A of the minor. The internship supervisor provides the students with content focused feedback, so they can successfully finish their internship assignment. Secondly, the internship coordinator supervises all students in Part B on personal, organisational or administrative issues. Thirdly, a local supervisor supports the students in their host country.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the internship students are able to:

column2: • Apply and extend the knowledge and skills acquired in the theoretical part of the minor in a specific context and practical assignment;
• Collaborate with other students with a different (disciplinary/study) background;
• Clearly define and shape the contribution of their own field in solving a specific problem of frugal innovation (scientific or other);
• Work in a different cultural environment from their own;
• Show an open mind and attitude which is sensitive to different cultural contexts;
• Communicate and present on frugal innovation to academic and non-academic audiences.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

You can integrate your internship with the thesis, running parallel to the thesis trajectory, for example, or you can do it after you have written your thesis. The minimum requirement is 6 full weeks, or the part-time equivalent, and you will be supervised by a company supervisor and an academic supervisor.

There are no ready-made internships nor placements. The internships are individual and therefore enormously variable, and it is up to you to secure a place. Through the Career Development Programme you will learn how to prepare a suitable application and the Career Development Manager will help you further during the individual coaching sessions. You will also have plenty of chance to connect with the companies where you could do your internship, as the Career Development Programme comprises activities with our Corporate Partners and RSM Alumni.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>An internship enhances your practical skills and provides excellent preparation for your first job, so it has become an important part of the MSc F & I Advanced curriculum. It can be in the form of a regular internship, a traineeship, or training on the job, and you can choose to work for corporate organisations, financial firms or government agencies.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In their second year, IBCoM students are required to take an internship in the field of communication and media. This internship can take place in a variety of fields, such as marketing, management, sales, corporate communications, public relations, internal communications, government, public affairs, education, journalism, the media and entertainment industries as well as the arts. This internship will enable students to train their communication and analytical skills and to apply their academic knowledge and skills in the professional world. Students are expected to work at a professional level, undertaking any tasks that are normally completed in the workplace of a company or organization. They should be practically oriented and be able to apply their academic insights and skills creatively and effectively in ""real world"" settings. On the internship pages on MyEur you can find the most relevant information about the internship and the internship manual.
Note: Students should have completed the course Communication and Media Labour Market Orientation (CM2008) before they may start with the internship (CM3041) in BA-2.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge, understanding and awareness of:

column2: • Labor market prospects and (international) career opportunities for graduates in communication and media
• Practical applications of their academic knowledge and skills, while also acquiring additional knowledge and expanding and improving practical skills
• Expectations and requirements of (international) employers and internship providers in a variety of relevant fields

column1: Students have developed the skills and/or the mindset to:

column2: •  Identify and reflect on their personal learning needs and interests (career goals and learning objectives)
•  Orientate themselves on the (international) job and internship market, apply for an internship and develop an internship plan/report
• Work together with colleagues/clients from different cultural backgrounds and to critically reflect on their own intercultural competencies
• Grasp how a particular (international) company, organization or industry works and build professional networks in the field of their choice
• Testing a career interest and their own suitability for that career

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82231,2018,Internship,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['CHE Reinhoudt - den Boer, MSc', 'dr. JWM Weggelaar - Jansen', 'F Feuerstake, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het duale traject / internship is opgezet vanuit de gedachte dat de dagelijkse management- en beleidspraktijk in organisaties jou in staat stelt om wetenschappelijke inzichten (kennis) te leren combineren en praktische vaardigheden te ontwikkelen (kunde). Door theorie en praktijk met elkaar te verbinden, krijg je inzicht in de relevante competenties voor een zorgmanager, beleidsmedewerker, projectleider enzovoorts. Naast de studie, werk je als stagiair samen met een ervaren manager, adviseur of staflid (met minimaal 5 jaar werkervaring op HBO+ niveau) aan opdrachten in een organisatie binnen de gezondheidszorg.

Een ‘gewone’ stage heeft doorgaans tot doel om inzicht te verkrijgen in het toekomstige werkveld en de dagelijkse werkpraktijk en werk je onder supervisie van een ander. Hoewel dit ook in het duale leertraject / internship doelen zijn, stellen we vooral eisen aan het kunnen vormgeven van je eigen ontwikkeling naar een zelfstandig functionerende zorgmanager. Tijdens het uitvoeren van taken en projecten voor de stage organisatie werk je aan het bereiken van jouw persoonlijke leerdoelen met betrekking tot inhoudelijke ontwikkeling binnen het kennisgebied Healthcare Management [HCM], professioneel gedrag [PG] en persoonlijke ontwikkeling [PO]. In algemene zin heeft het duale leertraject de volgende doelen:

column2: • Het verbreden van kennis en ervaring met het werken in een organisatie in de gezondheidszorg; dit omvat ook het eigen maken van ‘professioneel’ gedrag, het verbeteren van interpersoonlijke vaardigheden en inzicht krijgen in sterke en zwakke persoonlijke eigenschappen;
• Het verdiepen van inhoudelijke kennis van de studie met inzichten uit de praktijk, alsook het vertalen van theorie naar praktijk;
• Het toepassen van theoretische modellen en concepten om tot onderbouwde oplossingen voor een praktijkprobleem te komen;

• Het verbreden van kennis over en inzicht in de verschillende fasen van adviestrajecten, besluitvormings- en beleidsvormingsprocessen, projectmanagement, verandermanagement, en de rol van leiderschap in deze processen;
• Het ondersteunen in de eerste stap van een professionele carrière door het opdoen van relevante werkervaring in de gezondheidszorg.

column1: Vanzelfsprekend vergt dit extra inzet bovenop de normale studielast en moet je goed plannen om de studie en duale leertraject succesvol af te kunnen ronden.

column2: • Tijdens je studie werken als trainee van een zorgmanager, stafmedewerker of beleidsmedewerker bij een organisatie in de zorgsector.
• Bovenop de normale studielast, dus extra inzet en motivatie vereist
• Mogelijk in de voltijdopleiding als in de deeltijdopleiding (bij voorkeur in het eerste jaar)
• Duur: minimaal 5 maanden
• Werkdagen: minimaal 2 dagen per week (voor voltijds studenten bij voorkeur maandag en woensdag)
• Vergoeding: te bepalen in overleg met de organisatie.

column1: Het duale leertraject / internship is geen ‘doorsnee’ vak en dat geldt dus ook voor de beoordeling: je krijgt geen cijfer voor dit vak, wel een ‘Voldaan (VD)’. Om tot een beoordeling te kunnen komen, stel je bij de start van jouw stage in samenspraak met jouw begeleider in de gastorganisatie een aantal persoonlijke leerdoelen op en maak je afspraken over het werken aan de algemene leerdoelen. Gedurende jouw stage bespreek je jouw voortgang en ervaringen regelmatig met jouw begeleider van de gastorganisatie. Daarnaast heb je digitaal en persoonlijk contact met de coördinator van het duale traject via het online stage dagboek/journal. Ter afronding van jouw stage voer je een functioneringsgesprek en legt dit vast. Op basis van dit verslag wordt een eindgesprek gepland met vertegenwoordiger van ESHPM, stagebegeleider en jou.
Het duale leertraject / internship is 5 ECTS.
Ben je enthousiast geworden over het duale leertraject in de master Health Care Management?
Schrijf je dan in voor dit keuzevak. In het coursebook vind je meer informatie en ook in de startweek van de master Health Care Management geven we meer informatie.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Het internship / duale leertraject is weggelegd voor goede en gemotiveerde studenten, die bereid zijn om zich actief in te zetten voor een goed studieresultaat én een verbeterd carrièreperspectief.

Het duale leertraject is een van de keuze vakken in de master Health Care Management. Gedurende een periode van minimaal vijf maanden voor twee dagen per week (minimaal 360 uur) ga je naast jouw studie werken bij een organisatie in de zorg (zoals zorgorganisatie, zorgverzekeraar, ministerie VWS, koepelorganisatie, IGZ). Je krijgt de kans om jouw persoonlijke vaardigheden te spiegelen aan ervaren managers en verder te ontwikkelen in opdrachten. Bovendien geeft het duale leertraject jou een mooie voorsprong bij het zoeken naar een passende baan na het afstuderen. Het internship / duale leertraject is zeker ook interessant als je al werkzaam bent in de zorg. Tijdens het duale leertraject krijg je namelijk de kans om je op een ander niveau (management- of beleidsniveau) je verder te ontwikkelen. Afgelopen jaren maakte meer dan de helft van de studenten gebruik van deze mogelijkheid. Het is voor deeltijd studerende studenten mogelijk om het internship / duale leertraject ook in het buitenland te doen.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The internship is an introduction with the professional practice and an exercise in the skills which are relevant in the profession. The students gain experience in applying knowledge and at the same time acquire new knowledge and skills. During the internship 7 points for attention are central. These 7 points are important during the internship and the reporting of the internship. At each point of attention is formulated a number of objectives. These objectives apply to all forms of internship. The starting point is that all objectives be realized during the internship at the institution. However, due the nature of the different forms of internship certain objectives will be more or less on the foreground. The internship committee determines whether there can be met within the placement to the different objectives (based on the internship request).</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: The Master internship is an important component of the Master Family Pedagogy. During the first phase of the Master you have gained pedagogicalal knowledge and skills, now is the time to apply this acquired knowledge and skills into practice. The internship is the opportunity to deepen or broaden your content. This internship can give you a good overview of the labor market, the field and the requirements of employers. You can gain work experience and make valuable contacts, which you can use in your future career.
The student has knowledge and insight of:

• work within the pedagogical and/or educational profession at local level and/or at (inter)national level and the way in which these activities are relate to other institutions that directly or indirectly deal with issues in education and parenting.
• current pedagogical and/or educational issues and the current state of science and/or practice.
• the policy, protocols and/or processes of professionals in the pedagogical and/or educational professions.
• diversity issues within the pedagogical and/or educational practice and/or science.
• ethical and legal frameworks for pedagogical and/or educational act.
• performing and interpreting scientific pedagogical and/or educational research.
• apply the scientific knowledge (acquired during the study) in the professional practice.
• translate complex pedagogical and/or educational problems to (potential for) suitable interventions, programs and/or policies and to carry a valid basis.
• share professional development with professionals in the field.
• reflect scientifically on pedagogical and/or educational ethical issues.
• reflect scientifically and ethical on the interaction between the interest of science, policy and practice.
• oversee the research process and the diagnostic cycle.
• make responsible ethical and procedural decisions during the diagnostic and research cycle.
• reflect critical on their own insights and skills and those of others.
• apply, under supervision, (diagnostic) instruments, even at individuals and groups with different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
• report, scientifically sound, in written and oral form about plans and research (both focused on treatment/ intervention and research itself) and resulting recommendations, problems and solutions.
• assume an academic / advisory role in a cooperative relationship with professionals.

• set up, execute and evaluate a research or intervention or training programme in the field of education and/or parenting problems, preferably also at individuals and groups with different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
• provides a scientific contribution to (developing) policy, practice or research within an pedagogical context.
• work in a multidisciplinary group in pedagogical and/or educational practice.
• cooperate and communicate with different target groups (such as children, parents, teachers, policymakers and scientists).
• cooperate and communicate effectively and respectful with individuals with different backgrounds (such as nationality, culture, socio-economic environment and scientific discipline).
• ask for feedback on the work carried out, and here to receive to deal adequate with it.
• reflect on their own learning (and development herein) and to determine what are personal goals and interests.
In addition to the objectives set out the course, the student will also formulate personal goals to encourage the professional development.

The domains, independence (ig. Mostly know him/her to do, take action itself), establish contacts (ig. Can cooperate professionally with different target groups), communication (ig. Has good listening and communication skills) and professionalism (ig. respects appointments, is open to and processed on an adequate feedback), are important aspects herein.
